Timbs v. Indiana comes on a writ of certiorari to the Indiana Supreme Court. When Tyson Timbs pleaded guilty to a drug charge, he was ordered as part of his sentence to forfeit his Land Rover, on the grounds that he had transported drugs in the vehicle. A state appeals court ruled in favor of Timbs, who argued that the forfeiture was unconstitutional under the Eighth Amendment's clause prohibiting excessive fines. The Indiana Supreme Court reversed the decision, stating that the U.S. Supreme Court had never ruled that the excessive fines clause applied to state governments.

It seems that if Indiana had not confiscated the vehicle under civil law and instead had done it as part of criminal law, then it would have clearly exercised its right to confiscate property involved in the crime.  As it is now, in my understanding, the case pits a state law versus the federal law, and this SCOTUS will air towards the Indiana SC's ruling.  Curiously, the excessive fine portion of the eighth amendment is the only part of it not incorporated: https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/incorporation_doctrine .  This was upheld as recently as 2010: https://www.law.cornell.edu/supct/cert/08-1521

It seems that Timbs is arguing that the forfeiture of his vehicle was an integral part of his punishment for selling and trafficking heroin. Under Indiana criminal law, the maximum fine that could be imposed for that particular offense and subsequent conviction is $10,000 and his vehicle is worth 4 times that. If the Eighth amendment is understood to apply to states AND the circumstances of the confiscation are understood to be directly connected, then his claim should be upheld by the SCOTUS.
The state of Indiana is arguing that the vehicle was seized under a separate act to his criminal prosecution, in a civil case. Due to TImbs admission while in custody that he routinely used the vehicle to transport heroin, there is a case to be made that the forfeiture of his vehicle was related to confiscation of a vehicle used for illegal activity.
